information_requirement: Is an adversary attempting to inhibit response functions by blocking serial COM ports?

evidence.description: A TCP connection to a known serial-to-Ethernet converter port is established and remains open for an unusually long duration with little to no data transfer, preventing legitimate connections.
evidence.nai: Network segments containing serial-to-Ethernet converters, PLCs, and RTUs.
evidence.action: Identify the IP addresses and TCP ports of known serial-to-Ethernet converters. Analyze Zeek conn.log, filtering for connections to these target devices. For each connection, calculate the duration and total bytes transferred (orig_bytes + resp_bytes). Establish a baseline of normal connection durations and data volumes for these specific ICS devices. Use statistical methods to flag connections where the duration is in the top percentile (e.g., >99th) and the data transfer rate is anomalously low (e.g., <1st percentile). A connection exhibiting both characteristics is a strong indicator of an attempt to block the serial COM port.

evidence.description: An unusual or unauthorized source host initiates a connection to a serial-to-Ethernet converter.
evidence.nai: IT/OT network boundary, engineering workstations, and serial-to-Ethernet converter network segments.
evidence.action: Maintain an allowlist of authorized IP addresses (e.g., HMIs, engineering workstations) permitted to connect to specific serial-to-Ethernet converters. Monitor Zeek conn.log for any connections where the source IP (id.orig_h) is not on the allowlist for the destination converter IP (id.resp_h) and port (id.resp_p). On the source host, correlate the connection timestamp with process creation events (Windows Event ID 4688) to identify the process (e.g., telnet.exe, netcat) that initiated the unauthorized connection.
